Method Detail

build

public repast.simphony.context.Context<java.lang.Object> build(repast.simphony.context.Context<java.lang.Object> context)

We perform the initialization, specifically: (i) parse the cell data file, (ii) create the used space, grid instances, and initialize the value layer associated with the displayed grid, (iii) populate the grid with Bug, Predator and HabitatCell agents.

Below Model 15, the world was an idealized toric world. Version Model 15 and 16 uses real data, and toroidal borders were eliminated and replaced by strict borders.

Specified by:
build in interface repast.simphony.dataLoader.ContextBuilder<java.lang.Object>
See Also:
ContextBuilder.build(repast.simphony.context.Context)

createBugs

private void createBugs(repast.simphony.context.Context<java.lang.Object> context,
                        repast.simphony.space.continuous.ContinuousSpace<java.lang.Object> space,
                        repast.simphony.space.grid.Grid<java.lang.Object> grid)
Create the specified number of Bug agents and assign them to the space and the grid.

Parameters:
context - context to assign for the bug agents; should not be null
space - space to assign for the bug agents; should not be null
grid - grid to assign for the bug agents; should not be null
Since:
Model 15

createPredators

private void createPredators(repast.simphony.context.Context<java.lang.Object> context,
                             repast.simphony.space.continuous.ContinuousSpace<java.lang.Object> space,
                             repast.simphony.space.grid.Grid<java.lang.Object> grid)
By specification, 200 predator objects are intialized and randomly distributed as the Bug agents are. A cell may contain a Predator as well as a Bug, so we do not have to deal with any validation about the placement.

Parameters:
context - context to assign for the predator agents; should not be null
space - space to assign for the predator agents; should not be null
grid - grid to assign for the predator agents; should not be null
Since:
Model 16

createHabitatCells

private void createHabitatCells(repast.simphony.context.Context<java.lang.Object> context,
                                java.util.List<CellData> cellData,
                                repast.simphony.space.grid.Grid<java.lang.Object> grid,
                                repast.simphony.valueLayer.GridValueLayer foodValueLayer)
Fill up the context with cells, and add them to the created grid. Also set the initial food values for the value layer.

Parameters:
context - context to assign for the cell; should not be null
cellData - parsed cell data from the specified input file to create the cell agents; should not be null
grid - grid to assign for the cell; should not be null
foodValueLayer - value layer to assign for the cell; should not be null
Since:
Model 15

activateAgents

public void activateAgents()
In Model 9, we have to create a randomized order of agent execution. Please note it is the default behaviour in the previous model versions: methods scheduled for the same time steps with the same priority are executed in a random order by default.

This method gathers the current Bug agent list, randomizes its order, and calls their step() and grow() functions sequentially after each other.

Using the annotation ScheduledMethod makes this method executed from the first simulation tick, and with specifying interval it is executed each tick afterwards.

Since:
Model 9, Model 10, Model 12

getBugList

protected java.util.ArrayList<Bug> getBugList()
Returns the current active Bug agent list.

This would have done easier by keeping a simple reference for the context built during build(Context), or by keeping a reference for the created agents. However, we show here a general solution that may be used all of the time without any external modification to access all of the agents from a specified subclass.

Returns:
list of bugs associated with the master (root) context
Since:
Model 9

bugCount

public int bugCount()
A simple method to get the total number of current Bug population which is used to create the Population Abundance Graph.

Returns:
the current number of existing Bug agents in the root context; or 0 if the simulation is not yet initialized or no master context is available
Since:
Model 13
